abstract: A rash of small business contests has turned small business owners into get-out-the-vote advocates — for their own companies.
snippet: A rash of small business contests has turned small business owners into get-out-the-vote advocates — for their own companies.
lead_paragraph: Lately it’s not just the presidential candidates who are seeking votes. With the increasing popularity of small business contests, entrepreneurs are also orchestrating their own get-out-the-vote efforts. Contests exist in just about every niche. StartupNation is currently running its second annual contest for home-based businesses, sponsored by Microsoft Office Live Small Business. American Express sponsors the Make Mine a Million and Micro to Millions contests through Count Me In, which awards loans as well as business coaching and other support to qualifying female-owned businesses. Others, like Ideablob, from the credit card issuer Advanta are more general — $10,000 monthly prizes are awarded to anyone with a winning business idea.

headline.main: Entrepreneurs Get Out the Vote, for Themselves
